title: Canadian Space Agency offers funding for dual-use technologies
summary:
SYDNEY, Australia – Canada’s recently announced defense industrial strategy provides funding for space technologies with civil and military applications, Canadian Space Agency President Lisa Campbell said at the International Astronautical Congress here. “Satellite servicing, refueling, sustainable access to orbit, advanced robotics, artificial intelligence applications, critical deep space systems and cybersecurity have applications for defense but […]
The post Canadian Space Agency offers funding for dual-use technologies appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Canada’s recently announced defense industrial strategy provides funding for space technologies with civil and military applications. More than 13 million Canadian dollars will be awarded to 17 Canadian companies developing space technology with dual-use applications. The Canadian Space Agency will spend $5 million on projects that expand the use of satellite imagery and data.

title: Axiom Space taps Portuguese physiologist as first ‘Project Astronaut’

This pilot program is designed to test out a six-month astronaut training protocol, stemming from his background in physiology and sports science.

title: No Deal Yet To Avert Shutdown Tomorrow Night
summary: President Trump and congressional leaders left their meeting at the White House this afternoon with no deal to avert a government shutdown at midnight tomorrow night. If nothing changes, agencies […]
detailed_news: President Trump and congressional leaders left their meeting at the White House this afternoon with no deal to avert a government shutdown at midnight tomorrow night. If nothing changes, agencies like NASA will have to pause all non-essential operations at 12:01 am Wednesday after FY2025 ends with no appropriations for FY2026. House Republicans passed a “clean” Continuing Resolution (CR) on September 19 to keep the government operating at full strength through November 21. The House can pass legislation with a simple majority, but the Senate needs 60 votes to pass this type of bill. Shutdowns are caused by a lapse in appropriations and impact activities funded in the 12 appropriations bills. During a shutdown, essential operations including those to protect life and property continue, although workers are not paid until the shutdown ends. At NASA, operations of the International Space Station, for example, will not be affected.

title: Report claims NASA taking illegal steps to implement budget proposal
summary:
As the federal government nears a potential shutdown, a report by Senate Democrats alleges that NASA is already taking steps in to carry out the administration’s proposed budget.
The post Report claims NASA taking illegal steps to implement budget proposal appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Senate Democrats say NASA is taking steps in to carry out the administration's proposed budget. The budget proposal sought a nearly 25% cut in NASA’s overall budget in 2026. Appropriations bills pending in the House and Senate largely reject that cut. The report comes as NASA and the rest of the federal government faces a potential shutdown. Jeff Foust has a Ph.D. in planetary sciences from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He also has a bachelor’s degree with honors in geophysics and planetary science... title: Ground testing anomaly destroys Firefly Aerospace’s Alpha booster intended for next flight
summary: The anomaly came about a month after the FAA issued a Return to Flight determination for Firefly’s Alpha rockets following an anomaly experienced during Alpha Flight 6 in April.
detailed_news: The booster designated for Alpha Flight 7 “experienced an event that resulted in a loss of the stage,” the company said in a statement. A week before the incident, CEO Jason Kim said he expected Firefly to resume launches in the “coming weeks” Firefly Aerospace launched its Alpha rocket Friday after a launch attempt on Wednesday was scrubbed by bad weather. During Flight 4, also known as “Fly the Lightning,” Firefly saw a guidance, navigation and control (GNC) issue on the rocket’s second stage that prevented it from achieving its planned orbit.

title: Launch Roundup: Falcon 9 launches Starlink and Kuiper satellites
summary:
SpaceX is scheduled to launch up to three times this week, with each mission planned…
The post Launch Roundup: Falcon 9 launches Starlink and Kuiper satellites appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: SpaceX is scheduled to launch up to three times this week, with each mission planned to deploy internet communications satellites into low-Earth orbit. China kicked off the week’s launch manifest, for those in UTC, with the launch of its 100th Chang Zheng 2D rocket in the early hours of Monday morning. SpaceX will launch its third and final batch of satellites for Amazon’s Project Kuiper constellation. The mission is currently set to liftoff on Friday, Oct. 3, at 11:43 PM EDT (06:30 UTC on October 4), in the middle of a short 27-minute launch window. Onboard will be 28 more Starlink v2 Mini satellites, bound for an orbit at an altitude of 595 km, inclined at 53 degrees. Booster B1097 will make its second flight, having debuted only weeks ago at the start of September, launching a mission for Starlink's Group 17 shell.  NASASpaceflight.com will be taking part in the 25th anniversary of the first space shuttle mission in September 2025. The space shuttle program will take part in a series of missions over the course of 15 years. The first mission will take place on September 22, 2025, with the second and final mission scheduled for September 23, 2025.

title: New File Download Process for PSI Large Requests
summary: A recent update to the PSI database improves how large dataset downloads are handled, resulting in more efficient processing for users. Download requests larger than 1GB are now delivered via email, rather than downloading directly from the website. This allows the system to prepare your files in the background so you can continue working without […]
detailed_news: A recent update to the PSI database improves how large dataset downloads are handled. Download requests larger than 1GB are now delivered via email, rather than downloading directly from the website. This allows the system to prepare your files in the background so you can continue working without delays.

title: Joe A. Adam Presents Ring Sheared Drop (RSD) Research at 2025 ISSRDC
summary: At the virtual 2025 ISS Research and Development Conference (ISSDRC), Joe A. Adam of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, presented the topic titled “Surface Science in Microgravity – Fluid Geometry in the Ring-Sheared Drop,” presented to a broad audience from academia and the scientific community during the Physical Sciences and Materials Development session. Dr. Adam provided a […]
detailed_news: The Ring Sheared Drop (RSD) enables researchers to isolate shear-induced aggregation processes relevant to neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. The RSD's custom camera configuration has enabled a novel fluid characterization technique known as Particle Tracking Velocimetry (PTV)

title: Hubble Surveys Cloudy Cluster
summary: This NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image released on Sept. 12, 2025, features a cloudy starscape from an impressive star cluster. This scene is in the Large Magellanic Cloud, a dwarf galaxy situated about 160,000 light-years away in the constellations Dorado and Mensa. With a mass equal to 10–20% of the mass of the Milky Way, the Large […]
detailed_news: The Large Magellanic Cloud is a dwarf galaxy situated about 160,000 light-years away. It is home to several massive stellar nurseries where gas clouds coalesce into new stars. This image marries observations made roughly 20 years apart, a testament to Hubble’s longevity.

title: Astronaut Candidates Get to Work at Johnson Space Center
summary: NASA announced its newest class of astronaut candidates on Sept. 22, 2025, at the agency’s Johnson Space Center in Houston. After the welcome ceremony, the 10 highly qualified individuals rolled up their sleeves and prepared for the next step in their journey to the stars: nearly two years of training to become flight-eligible for missions […]
detailed_news: NASA announced its newest class of astronaut candidates on Sept. 22, 2025. They will undergo nearly two years of training to become flight-eligible for missions to low Earth orbit, the Moon, and ultimately, Mars. Each candidate will receive flight training, learning to pilot or improving their current piloting skills through the T-38 supersonic jet. Many members of NASA’s active astronaut corps emphasize that the learning does not stop when astronaut candidate training ends. As NASA astronaut Frank Rubio, class mentor, told the group, “You’ll become part of a legacy of those who trained before you, continuing the adventure they started”

title: NASA’s Webb Telescope Studies Moon-Forming Disk Around Massive Planet
summary: NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope has provided the first direct measurements of the chemical and physical properties of a potential moon-forming disk encircling a large exoplanet. The carbon-rich disk surrounding the world called CT Cha b, which is located 625 light-years away from Earth, is a possible construction yard for moons, although no moons are […]
detailed_news: NASA's James Webb Space Telescope has provided the first direct measurements of the chemical and physical properties of a potential moon-forming disk encircling a large exoplanet. The carbon-rich disk surrounding the world called CT Cha b, which is located 625 light-years away from Earth, is a possible construction yard for moons. Webb is an international program led by NASA with its partners, ESA (European Space Agency) and CSA (Canadian Space Agency). Webb is solving mysteries in our solar system, looking beyond to distant worlds around other stars. To learn more about Webb, visit: https://science.nasa.gov/webb

title: Startup’s radiation shield tech could bring high-performance AI chips to space
summary:
Under a $4 million ‘TACFI’ contract, Cosmic Shielding will develop a tool to predict the performance in orbit of radiation-shielded AI computing chips and other electronics
The post Startup’s radiation shield tech could bring high-performance AI chips to space appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: A startup named Cosmic Shielding says it has found a way to close the technology gap that limits how much computing power satellites can carry into orbit. The Atlanta-based company developed a lightweight nanocomposite, branded Plasteel. Radiation is one of the main reasons satellites still rely on radiation-hardened chips that are often five to 10 generations behind the latest commercial designs. Cosmic Shielding is currently based in Atlanta but plans to relocate to Huntsville, Alabama. The startup has drawn high-profile advisors: former Pentagon officials Lisa Porter and Michael Griffin have joined its board. “We now have about seven active systems in space. We have about 10 scheduled for the next 12 months,” Barghouty said.

title: Webb studies moon-forming disc around massive planet
summary: The NASA/ESA/CSA James Webb Space Telescope has provided the first direct measurements of the chemical and physical properties of a potential moon-forming disc encircling a large exoplanet. The carbon-rich disc surrounding the world called CT Cha B, which is located 625 light years away from Earth, is a possible construction yard for moons, although no moons are detected in the Webb data. The disc offers insight into how the moons of Solar System gas giants like Jupiter might have formed.
detailed_news: The carbon-rich disc surrounding the world called CT Cha B, which is located 625 light years away from Earth, is a possible construction yard for moons. The disc offers insight into how the moons of Solar System gas giants like Jupiter might have formed. Our Solar System contains eight major planets, and more than 400 known moons orbiting six of these planets. In the coming year, the team will use Webb to perform a comprehensive survey of similar objects to better understand the diversity of physical and chemical properties in the discs around young planets. The insights could be useful as our Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer ( Juice ) makes its way to Jupiter, and as we prepare a future mission to orbit and land on Saturn's moon Enceladus.

title: A perspective on space: Preparing for 2075
summary:
Recognizing that space is now an integral component of present-day society, the Royal Society (the U.K. academy of sciences) has recently completed a report that explores the potential implications of space activities by 2075, aiming to stimulate discussion without predicting specific outcomes. It highlights the transformative impact of space exploration on industry, society and culture, […]
The post A perspective on space: Preparing for 2075 appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: The next decades will see increased exploration beyond near-Earth orbit, potentially establishing long-term bases on the moon and Mars. Advances in large reusable rockets, single-stage-to-orbit spaceplanes, and green propellants will both dramatically lower costs and increase access to orbit. Robotic and autonomous systems will continue to lead space exploration. Near-Earth and cis-lunar space is already a geopolitical arena, with military satellites and anti-satellite weapons signalling increasing potential for space-based conflict. Robust protocols, starting as guidelines like the Astra Carta, are essential to ensure equitable resource access, reliable communication and conflict prevention. Martin Sweeting has pioneered academic techniques and commercial applications of small satellites since the 1980s. He chaired the... summary: From the ESA Blogs.

In the coming decades, the European Space Agency (ESA) foresees transportation hubs in orbit around our planet providing logistic services much like airports or train stations on Earth. Frequent flights to space would benefit from completely reusable rockets.

title: Italy’s crossroads: build its own satellites or lean on Starlink while waiting for IRIS²
summary:
MILAN – A report from Italy’s space policy office questioned whether the country is underrepresented in the IRIS² program, the European Union’s planned public-private communication constellation for low and medium earth orbit, while acknowledging SpaceX has offered to provide Starlink services for the country. Combined, the two points raised new questions about Italy’s position on Starlink. Those […]
The post Italy’s crossroads: build its own satellites or lean on Starlink while waiting for IRIS² appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: A report from Italy’s space policy office questioned whether the country is underrepresented in the IRIS² program. It also acknowledged SpaceX has offered to provide Starlink services for the country. The two points raised new questions about Italy's position on Starlink. Italy must decide whether to push ahead with a national low-Earth orbit dual-use telecommunications constellation. Italy doesn’t view Starlink as an alternative to IRIS² but rather as a temporary integrative solution until Europe’s system becomes operative. A decision on whether to pursue a national constellation or rely on Starlink is expected later this year. The leaked report closes with a broader reflection on the strategic balance between Europe and the U.S.

title: Hubble observes dead star devouring Pluto-like object
summary:
With help from NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope in low-Earth orbit, scientists recently observed a Pluto-like…
The post Hubble observes dead star devouring Pluto-like object appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: With help from NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope in low-Earth orbit, scientists recently observed a Pluto-like object being “eaten” by its host star. The hungry star is a white dwarf — the dense, stellar core left behind after a low-mass star dies and blows away its outer layers. The white dwarf observed by Hubble is about the size of Earth but much heavier, at around half the mass of our Sun. The white dwarf was likely once a Sun-like star that hosted a suite of planets and circumstellar disks similar to the Kuiper Belt. As the fragments fall onto the white dwarf, the star accretes them, emitting primarily ultraviolet light and very little visible light. The team is planning to continue their observations of hungry white dwarfs in the infrared with the James Webb Space Telescope. title: Live coverage: SpaceX to launch 24 Starlink satellites on Falcon 9 rocket from Vandenberg SFB
summary: The Starlink 11-20 mission will see SpaceX’s Falcon 9 rocket fly on a south-easterly trajectory upon departure from Vandenberg Space Force Base. Liftoff from pad 4E is scheduled for 4:32 p.m. PDT (7:32 p.m. EDT / 2332 UTC).
detailed_news: The Starlink 11-20 mission is SpaceX’s 88th mission supporting its megaconstellation this year. The satellites were manufactured by Northrop Grumman and will provide both commercial broadband connectivity and military satellite communications in the northern polar region. If successful, this will be the 154th touch down for this vessel and the 513th booster landing to date.

title: Galactic Energy secures $336 million, nears debut of new reusable and solid rockets
summary:
Beijing-based Galactic Energy has raised what appears China’s largest disclosed round for a launch startup as it nears orbital test flights of new rockets.
The post Galactic Energy secures $336 million, nears debut of new reusable and solid rockets appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Beijing-based Galactic Energy has raised what appears China’s largest disclosed round for a launch startup. The company announced Series D financing of 2.4 billion yuan ($336 million) in a statement Sept. 28. The funding will be used for the Pallas series of reusable liquid propellant launchers and the Ceres-2 solid rocket. The rocket is an upgraded version of the Ceres-1. Launch will now take place “at an appropriate time” in the near future. The rocket was earlier slated for a test flight in the first half of the year. The Ceres-2 will have a payload capacity of 1,600 kg to 500-km LEO, and 1,300 kg to500-km SSO.

title: IAI’s Game-Changing Communication Satellites: Revolutionizing Global Connectivity

detailed_news: Israel Aerospace Industries (IAI) has emerged as a trailblazer, pushing the boundaries of satellite technology and transforming the way we communicate. IAI’s compact communication satellites provide unprecedented coverage, ensuring connectivity even in the most remote and underserved areas. These satellites are designed to be resilient against space debris and solar radiation, ensuring uninterrupted operations and longevity. IAI is redefining the future of space. IAI delivers turnkey, space-proven solutions tailored to mission success. Come meet IAI’s satellite experts at IAC 2025 – Booth #599, or contact us at iai-mth-sms@iai.co.il.

summary:
Purdue University will conduct a dedicated suborbital research flight with Virgin Galactic in 2027 carrying a professor, student and alumni.
The post Purdue University to fly dedicated suborbital research mission with Virgin Galactic appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Purdue University will conduct a dedicated suborbital research flight with Virgin Galactic in 2027. The flight, carrying five people, will be the first dedicated crewed sub Orbital research mission by a university. It will be led by Steven Collicott, a professor of aerospace engineering at Purdue. “I think the science leading the way in science is going to be pretty intensely exciting, and things happen pretty quick,” Collicott said. “That’s the only chance I’ll get to look out the windows. I look forward to that.”

title: NASA Marshall director steps down
summary:
The director of NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center has abruptly stepped down, becoming the third NASA center director to leave in recent months.
The post NASA Marshall director steps down appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Joseph Pelfrey announced he would no longer serve as director of the Alabama center. He did not give a specific reason for his departure but suggested he was leaving to allow NASA leadership to select its own choice. He is the third NASA center director to leave in recent months.

title: China boosts broadband, IoT and weather satellite fleets with flurry of launches
summary:
A flurry of launch activity has seen China add to an Internet of Things constellation, loft new broadband satellites and boost its weather satellite fleet.
The post China boosts broadband, IoT and weather satellite fleets with flurry of launches appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: A Long March 6A lifted off at 8:40 a.m. Eastern (1240 UTC) Sept. 27 from Taiyuan Satellite Launch Center in north China. The mission payloads are believed to be the 11th batch of Guowang broadband megaconstellation project. The launch came less than a day after China added to its Fengyun series of meteorological satellites. China is closing in on a new national record for launches in a calendar year ( currently 68, set in 2024 ). Of the launches, 56 have been successful, with the only failure coming in August. The next launch out of China is expected to be a Long March 2D rocket launching from Jiuquan early Sept. 29 UTC.

title: ArianeGroup Awards Contract for Components of 27 Ariane 6 Rockets
summary:
ArianeGroup has contracted MT Aerospace to deliver key components for 27 Ariane 6 rockets, covering flights 16 through 42. Germany’s MT Aerospace is one of the Ariane 6 programme’s largest contractors, providing around 10% of the entire launch vehicle. The company supplies components for the cryogenic storage tanks and metallic structures of both the upper […]
The post ArianeGroup Awards Contract for Components of 27 Ariane 6 Rockets appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: MT Aerospace is one of the Ariane 6 programme’s largest contractors, providing around 10% of the entire launch vehicle. The company supplies components for the cryogenic storage tanks and metallic structures of both the upper and core stages. MT Aerospace is responsible for producing the carbon-fibre-reinforced plastic tanks that will store liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen.

title: ‘Left of launch’ becomes central focus in next-generation missile defense
summary:
Gen. Stephen Whiting: ‘Our missile defenses have done a good job during the most recent conflicts, but most of those are focused on terminal engagement, and we want to be able to push that engagement to the left and eventually left of launch.’
The post ‘Left of launch’ becomes central focus in next-generation missile defense appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: “Left of launch” refers to measures aimed at preventing or delaying missile launches. “We are seeing both the capacity and the capability of the threat missiles we’re now facing rapidly increase,” Gen. Stephen Whiting says. Whiting has been a proponent of closer “space-cyber-SOF” collaboration. The Air Force and the Space Force are studying options to field a new layer of AMTI satellites. “We want to be able to do a better job of helping to track those threats from space,” said Whiting. The discussions are taking place as the Pentagon embarks on an ambitious defense initiative. Companies will be challenged to design prototype SBI systems capable of intercepting missiles both within the atmosphere and after they enter space. “Like everyone in the industry, we’re following this,” Mitrevski said. � “We’m ready to provide solutions.”

title: From City Lights to Moonlight: NASA Training Shows How Urban Parks Can Connect Communities with Space Science
summary: When you think about national park and public land astronomy programs, you might picture remote locations far from city lights. But a recent NASA Earth to Sky training, funded by NASA’s Science Activation Program, challenges that assumption, demonstrating how urban parks, wildlife refuges, museums, and green spaces can be incredible venues for connecting communities with […]
detailed_news: NASA Earth to Sky partnered with the National Park Service and U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to deliver an innovative astronomy training program. The training empowered participants by affirming that everyone is an effective stargazer and night sky storyteller. The course also created a lasting community connection to NASA. Earth to Sky works with park interpreters and nonformal educators to share NASA space science. Learn more about how Science Activation connects NASA science experts, real content, and experiences with community leaders to do science in ways that activate minds and promote deeper understanding of our world and beyond.

title: NASA Awards Custodial, Landscaping Services Contract
summary: NASA has selected Melwood Horticultural Training Center Inc. of Upper Marlboro, Maryland, to provide custodial, janitorial, landscaping, and recycling services for the agency’s Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland. The Facilities Custodial and Landscaping award is a firm-fixed-price hybrid completion and indefinite-delivery/indefinite-quantity contract. The contract includes one 12-month base period and up to four […]
detailed_news: Melwood Horticultural Training Center Inc. of Upper Marlboro, Maryland, will provide custodial, janitorial, landscaping, and recycling services for the agency's Goddard Space Flight Center. The contract includes one 12-month base period and up to four 12- months options with a potential contract value of approximately $36 million.

title: Beyond Gravity to supply robotic arm thrusters for Swissto12 small GEOs
summary:
Beyond Gravity has secured a contract to deliver robotic arm thruster pointing mechanisms for the small satellites Swissto12 is building for geostationary orbit.
The post Beyond Gravity to supply robotic arm thrusters for Swissto12 small GEOs appeared first on SpaceNews.
detailed_news: Swissto12 is building small satellites for geostationary orbit. Beyond Gravity has secured a contract to deliver robotic arm thruster pointing mechanisms. Multi-axis Appmax 3 arms will be longer than earlier models. Deliveries are slated between 2026 and 2027.

title: Preparation for East Coast Starship debut in 2026 continue to make progress
summary:
As SpaceX prepares for Starship’s Flight 11 in October from Texas, significant progress is being…
The post Preparation for East Coast Starship debut in 2026 continue to make progress appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: The first of four M900F tower cranes that will be used to build the Starship Florida Giga bay has risen. Crews have nearly caught up in the construction timeline and have even diverted from it. SpaceX is rapidly expanding its Starship program, with teams working in parallel to conduct test flights. The launch mount for the LC-39A Starship Pad is not at that stage of construction. SpaceX may be taking a different approach, as it is expected to roll out in October with an LR13000 crane to be used for lifting it. There is still a lot of work to be completed on this pad, and it will likely not be operational until at least mid-2026.  NASASpaceflight.com is a nonprofit organization based in San Francisco, California. NASAS Spaceflight is dedicated to the advancement of space flight. The NASAS spaceflight program is funded by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASAS) NASASSpaceflight is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization.

title: NASA Helps Connect Astronomers and Community Colleges Across the Nation
summary: The NASA Community College Network (NCCN) and the American Astronomical Society (AAS) have teamed up to provide an exciting and impactful program that brings top astronomy researchers into the classrooms of community colleges around the United States. The Harlow Shapley Visiting Lectureship Program, named for astronomer Harlow Shapley (1885-1972), has a history dating back to […]
detailed_news: NASA Community College Network (NCCN) and the American Astronomical Society (AAS) have teamed up to provide an exciting and impactful program that brings top astronomy researchers into the classrooms of community colleges. The Harlow Shapley Visiting Lectureship Program has a history dating back to the 1950s, when it provided support for a scientist to give a series of astronomy-themed lectures. NASA's Parker Solar Probe became the first spacecraft to fly through the corona of the Sun. NASA’s Juno spacecraft entered orbit around Jupiter in 2016, the first explorer to peer below the planet's dense clouds. Webb is the premier observatory of the next decade, serving thousands of astronomers worldwide.

title: Lunar Challenge Winner Tests Technology in NASA Thermal Vacuum Chamber
summary: By Savannah Bullard One year after winning second place in NASA’s Break the Ice Lunar Challenge, members of the small business Starpath visited NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama, as part of their prize opportunity to test their upgraded lunar regolith excavation and transportation rover in the center’s 20-foot thermal vacuum chamber. The […]
detailed_news: Small business Starpath won second place in NASA’s Break the Ice Lunar Challenge. The company built a four-wheeled rover capable of excavating, collecting, and hauling material under extremely harsh environmental conditions that simulate the lunar South Pole. Starpath staff spent about three days at NASA Marshall in August, testing their robot with excavation and mobility trials while collecting data.
